title: Tuesday, 17th November, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Hi there

PM

Thought we might kick off with a piece of yesterday's news

PM

And it's a chart

11:01 am
PM

US news

PM

PM

Great example of cliff risk in biotech

11:02 am
PM

Clovis

PM

Company with a couple of lung cancer drugs

PM

FDA announced yesterday that it wanted more data

11:02 am
PM

And that's the result

BE

Ah, yes. What was more important than the FDA wanting more data was that the drug seems not to work very well.

BE

The wires focused on the first bit, because it's easy to understand.

11:03 am
PM

Ah, ok

PM

70% fall suggests the drug not working very well at all

BE

Yeah. The second bit is that the Clovis drug was shown to have a confirmed positive response rate of about 28 per cent to 32 per cent of patients.

11:04 am
BE

The unconfirmed response rate was above 50%.

PM

ie -- the company's earlier estimate?

BE

Yeah, basically. Though there's a reasonable amount of science behind this.

11:05 am
BE

A bit like oil companies' P10, P50, P90 estimates, if you like.

BE

Now, AstraZeneca had rush approval of its lung cancer drug on Friday

BE

Which showed a confirmed response rate of greater than 50%.

11:07 am
PM

Any indication of how much longer these drugs give you if you have lung cancer (asks a former fags professional)?

BE

No, I don't think we're at that point of knowing yet. And this is a very specific flavour of lung cancer.

BE

Small cell something something. It goes on for about fifteen words, which I can't attempt other than by cutting and pasting.

11:08 am
BE

AZN has a Phase III wider lung cancer test of its drug due 2017 I think.

BE

And it may be that Clovis tests were badly designed, or they're not equivalent, or something.

BE

We've many regulatory hoops to jump through yet.

11:09 am
BE

Though with Clovis's ability to raise cash now seriously impaired, one has to wonder whether public markets are the right way to fund these experiments.

BE

(I'm undecided on that point. Feel free to debate it on the right, if you wish.)

undefined
11:10 am
PM

So I want to know why the Footsie is up 2 per cent

PM

Bryce doesn't

PM

he says stocks go up and down most days

11:10 am
PM

But 2%!?!?

PM

On what?

PM

Deflation?

11:10 am
PM

Dec lift off "priced in" ??

BE

Well, I can tell you that the S&P was up 1.5%, best session in nearly a month.

PM

Wot?

11:10 am
BE

And WTI rallied off $40 to add 2.5%, $42ish.

PM

There's only two fallers int he footsie

BE

I know. And everyone's saying "It's following Wall Street and oil"

11:11 am
BE

Then when you ask, "okay, why Wall Street and oil?"

BE

.... they mumble something about market resilience into their sleeves.

BE

So, dunno.

11:11 am
BE

Markets are up because they are.

BE

Descartes markets.

PM

hehehehe

11:12 am
BE

Markets are because they are. That could well become a catchphrase here.

BE

Anyway, where should we begin? Smiths?

undefined
11:12 am
PM

Sure

BE

Results rubbish.

BE

Weaker than expected.

11:13 am
BE

Too early for new management to say anything strategic.

BE

John Crane even worse than thought, which was already pretty bad given it's effectively oil services.

BE

But, the pension's sort-of fixed.

11:13 am
BE

Sort of.

BE

Hence ....

Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,017, up 91.5 (+9.89%), High: 1,038, Low: 950.00, Volume: 1.32m
11:14 am
BE

Smiths cutting pension contributions by £36m per annum

BE

Reflecting a fall in the actuarial deficit

BE

And cutting off payments to an escrow account.

11:15 am
BE

Now, with the pension hole looking a bit better it's inevitable that folk will talk once again about breaking up Smiths

PM

ah, yes

BE

Though, clearly, it's way too early in managements' careers to think about that.

11:16 am
BE

Today's gain seems to have removed a fair bit of the conglomerate discount already.

BE

And it goes without saying that buyers are easier to find for the good bits than the bad bits.

BE

Sell medical and you're left with a very unattractive engineer, though I guess the likes of Melrose might take an interest in some bits.

11:18 am
BE

Anyway, winding back, here's Cazenove to summarise where we are.

BE

Given that the new CEO and CFO have only been in post since the end of
September, it is no surprise to see no comments on the group strategy. We
expect comment on strategy with the H1 results in March 2016. We estimate
the group pension is now in surplus on the back of the triennial review of the
SIPS. Given the recent fall in the oil price, we have trimmed our expectations
for John Crane resulting in a 2% cut to our 2017E EBITA. However, the
improved cash flow, the elimination of the pension deficit and the modest cut
to EBITA translates into an unchanged Dec-16 price target of 1,250p. With
35% potential upside to our price target, we are reiterating our Overweight
recommendation.

BE

 Triennial pension review. We believe the highlight of today’s release is
the elimination of the pension deficit as a result of the SIPS triennial review.
On an IAS 19 basis, we estimate the group overall now has a pension
surplus of ~£100m vs a deficit of £108m as of 31 July 2015. As result, total
cash contribution to SIPS should fall to £24m in 2017 from £60m in 2015.
We estimate the cash outflow to the pension schemes looks set to be around
£50m in 2017E, half the level of 2015. The increase in the cash generation
of the group should enable the management pursue a strategy of bolt-on
acquisitions while at the same time having a progressive dividend policy.

11:18 am
BE

 Q1 IMS. In Q1 2016, sales declined by 4% y/y which is in keeping with the
September guidance for a weak start to the year with improvements
expected in H2. Despite the dip in sales, the operating margin was broadly
unchanged y/y. John Crane saw First Fit customers’ weakness while
aftermarket was more resilient. Detection profitability improved, as
expected, and Medical recorded a solid performance. Smiths Interconnect
and Flex-Tek was broadly similar to Q1 last year.

BE

 2016E EPS trimmed by 3% on the back of ongoing oil price weakness.
Management’s expectations for the full year are broadly unchanged.
However, on the back of the recent weakness in the oil price, we have
trimmed our expectations for John Crane and this translates into a 3%
reduction in our 2016E EPS forecast.
 Valuation. Based on our revised forecasts for 2016E (July year-end), the
group is trading on prospective EV/EBITDA, EV/EBIT and PE multiples of
8.9x, 9.5x and 11.2x, respectively. Based on calendarised 2016E forecasts,
this leaves Smiths trading at a significant discount to the sector in terms of
PE and EV/EBITA multiples. We regard the dividend as very secure. The
2016E yield of 4.4% compares with a sector average of 3.2%.

BE

What all that boils down to is downgrades.

11:20 am
BE

"Broadly in line" means consensus is coming down. Five or 6 per cent, probably.

BE

But, today, no-one's decided to care.

undefined
11:20 am
PM

Allied irish mentioned over on the right

PM

Long time coming, this

PM

1-for-250 stock consolidation

11:20 am
PM

http://www.ise.ie/...s.aspx?ID=12584465

PM

I believe we were the first to point out the nuttiness here

PM

AIB capitalised at circa 90bn euros

11:21 am
PM

http://ftalphavill...jit-market-in-aib/

PM

People claimed it was a squeeze

PM

Was nothing of the sort

11:22 am
PM

Just idiot punters who thought the stock was cheap cos it as quoted in the range of 10 cents or so

PM

Anyway, fixing now

PM

Only took two years

11:22 am
undefined
PM

This stupid B&M discount retailer

PM

Well i guess it's not stupid

11:23 am
BE

Hm.

PM

Just offers an awful experience

PM

But people like cheap

11:24 am
PM

Not growing quite as quickly as hoped 9by some) it seems

BE

It's never a good idea to consensus shortly after floating

PM

http://www.investe...1511170700089164F/

11:24 am
PM

Miss consensus

BE

(It feels like shortly ... guess it's been more than a year)

BE

Yeah, expansion's not going as easily as the IPO sales pitch suggested.

11:25 am
BE

They bought a huge suburban Homebase near me, incidentally.

BE

B&M seems a less than ideal fit for that much floorspace

PM

Watch out, your neighbourhood will be flooded with Toyoto Hilux and the like

11:26 am
PM

Blokes driving trucks

BE

Even calling my neighbourhood a neighbourhood is stretching definitions .....

BE

Anyway, I'd guess the average visitor to a DIY shop puts down £100 or so

11:28 am
BE

And I'd guess the average visitor to B&M is buying grey market Chinese-made crap with tickets in single-digit pounds.

BE

It just doesn't seem a good fit. In fact, it seems a very bad one. Like putting Poundstretcher in a barn.

BE

Anyway, the upshot is a miss. Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:29 am
BE

B&M reported LFL up 1.2% in F1H15/16 below consensus at +2%, implying
F2Q16 LFL up only 1.3% vs. +1.1% in F1Q16 and 3.5% in F4Q15 despite the
company facing the easiest comps of the year (3.7% in F2Q14/15 vs. 6.0% in
F1Q14/15). Management attributed the weaker than expected LFL
performance to the disruptions related to the introduction of two new UK
distribution centers and a greater than budgeted store opening level. B&M
opened 47 net new stores in F1H15/16 ahead of the critical F3Q (25 stores in
F1Q and 22 in F2Q), in line with management guidance of 80 net new stores in
FY15/16e, and implying selling space expansion of 25.6% in F1H15/16.
Group gross margin declined by 20bps to 34.5% vs. consensus at 34.4% as the
negative USD impact was partially offset by the favorable product mix.
Similarly group adjusted EBITDA came in at £86.6m (in-line with consensus at
£86.8m) implying a margin down 55bps to 9.3% as the incremental operating
costs associated with the new distribution centers added to the gross margin
decline.
Looking ahead, the store opening targets remain unchanged and management
reiterated its expansion ambitions both in the UK and in Germany where the
group will increase the Jawoll store network to 55 (+6 new stores) this
calendar year. Moreover, while the 2Q LFL were impacted by some operational
disruptions due to the two new DC coming online, this should not affect the
third quarter which is critical for B&M as it account for almost 50% of profits.

BE

And Canaccord.

BE

B&M's interims saw group revenues increase strongly by 25.8% (26.8% at constant
currency) to £930.3m, with the core UK business delivering a 26.5% increase to
£861.7m, with the LFL sales growth component up 1.2%. The latter represents a
small improvement from the 1.1% figure at the Q1 stage. The company has said that
it is seeing an increasing cannibalisation effect from the rapid store expansion, and
estimates that LFL would have been +2.5% in the absence of cannibalisation (c 40
stores excluded).
The overall sales growth was driven as usual by new store openings. Within the UK, 47
net new stores were opened, with the company on track for 80 over the full year. Jawoll
opened two new stores, with three more slated ahead of Christmas.
Group gross margin was down 20bps to 34.5%, due to adverse FX rates ($ and euro),
partially offset by sales mix.
Group EBITDA, adjusting for store pre-opening costs of £4.5m, which B&M takes below
the line, increased 15.6% to £82.1m (£71.0m), vs B&M reported +18.6%. Our adjusted
PBT growth of 21.3% compares with the reported growth of 25.4%. On our adjusted
numbers, there has been some operational deleverage, with EBITDA margins down
around 75bps (vs B&M's reported 55bps decline) partly for reasons outlined below. An
interim dividend of 1.6p was declared, a substantial increase of 78% over last year's
0.9p.
There have been some growing pains, however, due to the high level of store openings
and the introduction of two new distribution centres, requiring early staff recruitment and
higher training costs. These, combined with a slower start to the Xmas peak due to mild
temperatures, have had an adverse impact on LFL sales in the build to peak.

11:30 am
BE

Impact on our view
In essence our view is unchanged - we are fans of the business model, but less
enthusiastic about the rating, which looks full and up with events in our view. The multiyear
roll-out potential in the UK is an attractive prop of the investment case, even without
the overlay of a potential roll-out in Germany. The company continues to deliver financial
deleverage, down from 2.8x net debt/adjusted EBITDA a year ago to 2.2x now. The group
is to consider the "most appropriate and efficient capital structure...over the coming
months", given its growth requirements and its highly cash generative model.
Valuation
The shares continue to trade at a significant premium to the sector, reflecting B&M's
superior growth rates. On a PER basis, they trade at 27.5x for cal 15E falling to 22.6x
for cal 16E. On an EV/EBITDA basis, the corresponding figures are 18.2x and 15.1x. We
maintain our 350p target price, based on a 2.0x EV/sales metric for cal 15E.

BE

And Numis, which was on the float here.

BE

Interim PBT increased by 25%, in line with expectations. The group is managing
a significant acceleration of its store openings while maintaining exemplary ROIC,
notwithstanding a modest LFL deflection in existing stores and mild short-term
pressure on cost ratios. The market backdrop suggests a degree of caution in terms
of near-term forecasts is advisable across the sector, but we believe that B&M's
unique format characteristics and growth outlook more than justify the current
valuation and would continue to Add to holdings.

11:31 am
BE

I don't quite understand "unique format characteristics"

PM

Unique format is that it's like a Poundland store, where you effectively have to travel round each isle in order to get out of the bloody place

PM

Having made the mistake of walking in in the first place

11:32 am
BE

Yeah. I once met an analyst who was a buyer of B&M and talked about the store for about 15 minutes.

BE

I was actually, unknowingly, talking about going to Wilco.

BE

And neither of us even realised.

11:01 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

Also: Tiger. That's comparable but better. The Ikea of cheap crap.

PM

Good for candles

11:33 am
BE

Yup. Anyway, let's move on.

undefined
PM

Actually there are Nielsen numbers out

11:33 am
PM

Grocers

PM

"LADs" doing well

PM

i thought this Aldi and Lidl stuff had peaked

11:34 am
PM

Maybe not

PM

A bit of Clive Black

PM

Aldi & Lidl pull away again
For the major superstore groups pressure also persists from the limited assortment discounters (LADs), which to our minds have ‘gone again’ in recent times with sales appreciation and so share gains accelerating. Indeed, the headline data points of this update from Nielsen are the strength of the sales momentum from the LADs; Aldi’s implied sales is said to be a whacking 27.5% ahead whilst Lidl’s also grew strongly by 21.7% yoy over the 12-week period. The combined UK share of Aldi & Lidl is said to be 11.1%.

The LADs’ growth reflects the combined impact of new space, set against the broad moratoria of the major superstore operators opening programmes (indeed the reverse in some cases), alongside strong same store progress, despite the constraints of over-trading, so jammed car parks and check-out queues. Such is the strength of the trading momentum of the LADs at this time, we are also expecting a stronger Christmas trade yoy, noting that in years gone-by the discounters have lost out to the superstores in the festive season. Maybe this year will be different, placing further pressure upon the superstore model.

11:35 am
PM

What's happening to our society?

PM

Aldi sales up 27 per cent ???

BE

Well, expansion does that.

11:35 am
PM

An an extra note from CLive...

PM

Note: Kantar data for the 12W to the 8th November is also out today. Kantar also records that the two LADs have share in excess of 10%, for the first time on its measure stating that an additional 1m shoppers visited Aldi & Lidl yoy with spend per basket 4% higher at these outlets. Lidl’s sales are said to be 19% yoy for the 12W, whilst Aldi is up by 16.5%. Sainsbury again outperforms the majors with 1.5% growth in sales, re-taking the No.2 spot in its league table whilst Asda recorded a 3.5% reduction in revenues, Tesco UK experienced a 2.5% sales decline and Morrisons a lesser 1.7% reduction.

BE

Bernstein makes an interesting point that Sainsbury, Lidl, Waitrose and M&S are the relative winners here.

11:36 am
BE

And Sainsbury, Lidl, Waitrose and M&S are all relatively reliant on the South East

BE

The data here might reflect nothing more than geographical lumpiness, for want of a better term.

BE

While on supermarkets, Citi's rejigged the sector.

11:37 am
BE

The key call being an upgrade to Tesco.

BE

Nick Coulter is the analyst. If you're a Citi client you can see a video of him explaining this.

BE

If you're not, you'll have to suffice with the text.

11:38 am
BE

 Upgrading Tesco to 1-Buy rating from 2-Neutral, (TP 230p, 39% upside) — The
backdrop for the UK grocery market remains challenging but we think Tesco has the
scope to be more competitive, to rebuild its profitability and to repair its balance
sheet. Although we are mindful of quarterly sales volatility (and specifically a
tougher Christmas comp) we believe with EBIT momentum set to increase and
asset optionality in reserve that the risk reward profile for the shares is skewed to
the upside. With the shares approaching their 10-year lows, we upgrade to 1-Buy
with a target price of 230p offering 39% upside, supported by our sum-of-the-parts
and DCF analysis.

BE

 Tesco needs to invest c.£600m in price — We believe the UK supermarkets need
to disrupt the discounters; we see no alternative. Whilst price is not the only
consideration, we estimate a multi-yr investment of £500-700m for its prices to close
the gap to 5-10%.
 But we estimate that better buying will release c.£1.5bn from CoGS — We
believe that by restructuring its category assortments, the ‘Commercial’ or ‘Product’
teams will be the key enabler of a competitive offer with sustainable economics.
 Range resets to drive earnings inflection — Tesco UK & Ireland was broadly
breakeven in H2 2014/15 and H1 margins remained subdued at 0.8%. Nonetheless
we believe the programme of end-to-end category resets will allow Tesco to begin a
multi-year recovery to c.3% margins, with volume growth as the key focus.
Korea enables B/Sh. to self-repair. Considerable asset optionality remains —
We estimate the Korea disposal will enable Tesco to trade its way back to an
investment grade credit rating in FY18/19. Tesco has concluded its asset review but
should funds be required, we believe Thailand (£6bn), Malaysia (£1bn), Tesco Bank
(£1bn), Dunnhumby and Telecoms all provide further options, with disposals
considered in preference to equity in our view.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 170.30, up 4.1 (+2.47%), High: 173.50, Low: 168.25, Volume: 15.48m
11:39 am
BE

Also downgrades Sainsbury

BE

Around which there remains a story we can't nail down, in spite of trying for most of last week.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 250.40, up 7.2 (+2.96%), High: 251.90, Low: 243.90, Volume: 4.19m
11:39 am
BE

 Moving to a 2-Neutral rating, (TP 265p) — We are encouraged by the volume
response to Sainsbury’s initiatives and back it to ‘manage through’ although we
believe this will entail negative LFLs and margin erosion for this year, next year and
probably the year after. Reflecting this trajectory we value the shares at 265p or
13.5x FY17/18E or “2017” EPS, and a 10% discount to the European food retail
sector.
 Execution leads to volume momentum — JS’s strategic review in Nov-14 faced
into the structural challenges of the UK grocery market to acknowledge the
unpalatable likelihood of multi-year negative LFLs. Nonetheless Sainsbury’s playbook
appears to be working with its execution leading to a marked volume-response
and the delivery efficiencies ahead of schedule.
 More to come — Although well-positioned (premium mass market, London/Southbias,
etc.) and ahead of a pragmatic plan, we think Sainsbury is well aware it cannot
afford to sit back in a grocery eco-system that includes Aldi, Lidl, Walmart and
Tesco. Whilst it has not been explicit, we expect JS to ‘go again’ with further price
investments funded by further efficiencies.
 Expecting negative LFLs and margin erosion for FY15/16E to FY17/18E — Our
forecasts include LFLs of (1.8)%, (0.6)% and (0.6)% and EBIT margins (40)bps,
(10)bps and flat in FY15/16E, FY16/17E and FY17/18E as Sainsbury continues to
execute. This puts us 3% ahead of FY15/16E EBIT consensus, 1% ahead of
FY16/17E, and inline with the market’s expectation for FY17/18E.
 Balance sheet stretched but not stressed — Lower profits have stretched
Sainsbury’s balance sheet to an adjusted net debt / EBITDA of 5x we estimate.
£1.15bn of covenantless-liquidity ensure this is not an operational constraint but any
mis-steps will sharpen investor focus in this area in our view.

BE

And Morrison goes down to sell.

BE

 Moving to a 3-Sell rating, TP130p, (14)% downside — with volumes stubbornly
negative despite over £500m of investment we think the FY16E/17E EBIT inflexion
expected by consensus is over-optimistic. Reflecting Morrison’s weaker operating
trends we target c.20% discount to the European sector PE or 13.5x FY16/17E EPS
of 9.6p to derive a 130p target price.
 Volumes yet to turn — Over half-way through its 3-year plan Morrison has
invested greater than £500m (4% sales) in its offer yet customer numbers and volume trends
have yet to turn. New CEO David Potts has rightly focused on retail basics and
costs but we expect volumes to remain stubbornly negative for FY15E/16E.
 With fewer levers to pull — Having deployed over half of its £1bn cost savings
target, we worry that Morrison’s historical virtues of an edited range and verticallyintegrated
manufacturing provide less opportunity as the industry necessarily
restructures its offers to combat the discounters. That said, we estimate
manufacturing continues to provide 1% of margin support as underlying retail
margins come under pressure.
 FY16/17E consensus EBIT inflexion a challenge — FY16E/17E EBIT consensus
shows YoY growth of 9%. This implies a combination of positive volumes, less
investment or a step-up in savings; each of which we believe to be a challenge.
 Citi FY16/17E EBIT (12)% below consensus — Our FY16/17E EBIT forecasts
reflect sustained investment, flat volumes (LFLs down (2)%) and continued cost
savings to deliver a (3)% decline in EBIT (before one-offs). We believe this would
represent a good outcome.
 Balance sheet & FCF give flexibility — Morrison’s balance sheet strength is a
clear positive with a 6% FCF yield to underpin an already I.G balance sheet (3.8x
adj. net debt / EBITDA)

11:40 am
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 154.53, up 0.8332 (+0.54%), High: 155.80, Low: 152.20, Volume: 2.42m
BE

So that's that.

undefined
11:41 am
PM

Easyjet needs a mention

PM

The figures looked good to me -- but Ms McCall makes no mention of the Paris attacks

PM

Or at least none in the statement

11:41 am
PM

http://www.investe...1511170700089174F/

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,710, down 73 (-4.09%), High: 1,754, Low: 1,703, Volume: 1.78m
PM

Figures were in line, no?

11:42 am
BE

Nope, no Paris guidance, as one would expect. And, yes, figures in line.

BE

Which isn't really good enough, particularly versus Ryanair which has been raising at every opportunity.

BE

Instead, EasyJet has sounded a bit cautious on cost inflation

11:43 am
BE

There are a lot of moving parts in here, so I'll turn to Morgan Stanley to talk us though them.

BE

We estimate EZJ's 1H16 building blocks, assuming 1.5% reduction as a
proxy for the 'slight decline' unit revenue guidance, could imply 1H
PBT of around last year's £7m level assuming currencies stay constant.
This includes ~£75m of fuel price benefit. No consensus is available for 1H16,
but FY expectation for FY16 is c£740m, growth of 7.8% Y/Y. We are 8% above
consensus at £800m implying a FY16 PE of 10.3x. The company notes they are
comfortable with the FY16 PBT consensus levels.

BE

Initial guidance into 1H16 in line with our expectation - but cost
inflation offsets solid revenue per seat outlook. 1H16 seat growth of ~8%
Y/Y and 7% on a FY basis. We currently expect 8.4% in 1H16 (based on OAG
schedules) and 6.0% for the FY, implying 6.2% in 2H. Constant currency rev per
seat is guided "to slightly decline" for 1H16 against a reported (including
currency) comp of +0.2%. Applying this guidance would imply a 2H rev / seat
decline of c3.3% (against reported comp of -2.7%) to maintain our FY -2.6%
estimate. Cost per seat ex fuel at constant currency is guided at +2% in FY, with
the increase weighted to the 1H16 to account for Egypt and Paris issues. We
assume a 0.4% reported decline in 2016e.

11:44 am
BE

- FY16 unit fuel in jet fuel range of $450 to $550m/tonnes (spot is at
$437m/tonne) is guided at £140 to £160m favourable impacts. FX at spot
(1.522 GBP/USD, 1.4106 GBP/EUR) is guided at 1H £15 adverse movement
and FY £40m adverse movement.
- An ordinary dividend of £219m declared at 40% payout. We had
assumed a special dividend of £175m (44p /sh) in an effort of balance sheet
optimisation, instead, the group ends the year with net cash of £435m.
- 4Q15 run rates on yield flat on a reported basis. FY15 PBT was delivered
at £686m, at mid point of guidance of £675-700m, and versus our £701m
estimate.
- Egypt repatriation costs and impact on Egypt forward bookings are included
in the cost guidance but not separately quantified. Our analysis of OAG seat
data indicates Egypt accounts for 0.8% of winter seat schedule, North Africa as
a whole is 2.7%; and Paris is 11.3% with France being 14.7%.

PM

hmm

PM

People are not going to stop visiting Paris; Egypt another matter I think

11:46 am
BE

Indeed not. As I say, it's largely the cost outlook rather than the demand outlook

BE

Plus the fact that, if you're a no-frills airline, a lot of buyers are waiting for you to grow into your valuation. No upgrades, no buyers.

undefined
11:47 am
BE

On Glencore, as noted on the right ...........

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 90.54, up 0.9991 (+1.12%), High: 93.98, Low: 90.16, Volume: 24.65m
BE

PM

PM

11:48 am

PM

PM

11:48 am
BE

BE

Because Glencore really really needs to sell stuff.

BE

Forgot to mention yesterday the figures from Katanga

11:49 am
BE

the DRC copper miner that's 75% owned by Glencore

BE

BE

11:50 am
BE

BE

Which'd be Glencore buying deeply discounted shares to pay off debt to itself. Not ideal.

PM

Onto subject headings ....

BE

Blue Monday
The major economies are now characterised by desynchronised economic cycles, with divergent
policy regimes. This complicates the equity investment decision. Europe may be a relative winner,
but too much of the globe is seeing financial conditions tighten, against lacklustre growth, to be
optimistic on directional trends. We see downside risk through the opening months of 2016.

BE

(Yes, that's New Order. Still counts.)

11:57 am
BE

Isolation
The European economy is moving in the right direction and further ECB action promises to again
ease financial conditions. Valuations may be rich and earnings forecasts too high, but on balance
Europe, in isolation, looks attractive. It’s the global backdrop that scares us.

BE

Love (of the dollar) will tear us apart
US macro resilience has long been the consensus default assumption. But US financial conditions
are tightening and the rate cycle looms. Corporate demand for credit has surged, and the 2016
refinancing wall looks onerous. A further rise in spreads, and the equity market may pay the price.
And this at a time when EM remain vulnerable – the structural concerns are still valid.

BE

From safety to where
We increase the Defensive bias to the portfolio. Sector allocation is skewed to the most obvious
beneficiaries of ECB policy and low euro-area yields. EM exposure still offers a poor risk-return payoff.
Our Financials preference is flipped in favour of Insurance to accommodate a lower for longer
interest rate trajectory. This all adds up to an increased allocation in low beta sectors.

11:59 am
BE

Our core sector portfolio ideas are focussed on the beneficiaries of ECB policy support
– an environment of sustained very low bond government bond yields. Infrastructure
and Regulated Utilities stocks may feature, but at the sector level its Telecom and Real
Estate that are the core buys on the theme.
We Neutralise ‘secular growth’, keeping Personal & Household Goods at Underweight,
upgrading Healthcare to Overweight, with Neutrals in Food & Beverage and Tech.
Sensitivity to any rise in the Treasury yield may work against them, their low volatility
characteristics will still appeal to many though.
Construction continues to hold the allure of a margin recovery play as top line growth
releases operational leverage. The quietly forgotten ‘Juncker plan’ may start to
positively influence demand as 2016 progresses.
Household disposable income growth looks like a clear euro-area macro thematic.
Unfortunately, we feel the pricing of the most obviously exposed sectors fully reflect
this. We downgrade and are now Neutral across the Consumer Cyclical group, but do
see a relative trade in Long Media (overweight), short Retail (underweight).
We make a significant change in Financials, upgrading Insurance to Overweight and
cutting Banks to Neutral. The motivation is simple enough – in an environment of
sustained QE and sovereign yield compression in Europe, which part of the Financials
universe comes out best? After working to mitigate duration mismatch over the course
of this year, Insurance now looks favourite.

BE

Turning to the shorts, we look to the EM exposed sectors, with the greatest sensitivity
to manufacturing, industrial production and credit conditions. Industrials, Chemicals and
Autos fall into this category – we are Underweight all three.
Oils and the Miners remain very difficult – big underperformers through 2015 as the
commodity price backdrop reflected both the weak demand trends and producer oversupply.
We have little confidence that demand is on the verge of showing a material
uplift. Oils we cut from Neutral to Underweight – on our numbers the rehabilitation is
simply too far out. We see greater appeal in Basic Resources but also recognise the
risks. We bite the bullet and cut to Neutral.

BE
